rule_id.description: A unique identifier for the rule.

type.description:
The type of rule.
`pinned` will identify and pin specific documents to the top of search results.
`exclude` will exclude specific documents from search results.

criteria.description:
The criteria that must be met for the rule to be applied.
If multiple criteria are specified for a rule, all criteria must be met for the rule to be applied.

actions.description:
The actions to take when the rule is matched.
The format of this action depends on the rule type.

type.description:
The type of criteria. The following criteria types are supported:

* `always`: Matches all queries, regardless of input.
* `contains`: Matches that contain this value anywhere in the field meet the criteria defined by the rule. Only applicable for string values.
* `exact`: Only exact matches meet the criteria defined by the rule. Applicable for string or numerical values.
* `fuzzy`: Exact matches or matches within the allowed Levenshtein Edit Distance meet the criteria defined by the rule. Only applicable for string values.
* `gt`: Matches with a value greater than this value meet the criteria defined by the rule. Only applicable for numerical values.
* `gte`: Matches with a value greater than or equal to this value meet the criteria defined by the rule. Only applicable for numerical values.
* `lt`: Matches with a value less than this value meet the criteria defined by the rule. Only applicable for numerical values.
* `lte`: Matches with a value less than or equal to this value meet the criteria defined by the rule. Only applicable for numerical values.
* `prefix`: Matches that start with this value meet the criteria defined by the rule. Only applicable for string values.
* `suffix`: Matches that end with this value meet the criteria defined by the rule. Only applicable for string values.

metadata.description:
The metadata field to match against.
This metadata will be used to match against `match_criteria` sent in the rule.
It is required for all criteria types except `always`.

values.description:
The values to match against the `metadata` field.
Only one value must match for the criteria to be met.
It is required for all criteria types except `always`.

ids.description:
The unique document IDs of the documents to apply the rule to.
Only one of `ids` or `docs` may be specified and at least one must be specified.

docs.description:
The documents to apply the rule to.
Only one of `ids` or `docs` may be specified and at least one must be specified.
There is a maximum value of 100 documents in a rule.
You can specify the following attributes for each document:

* `_index`: The index of the document to pin.
* `_id`: The unique document ID.

ruleset_id.description: A unique identifier for the ruleset.

rules.description: Rules associated with the query ruleset.

ruleset_id.description: A unique identifier for the ruleset.

rule_total_count.description: The number of rules associated with the ruleset.

rule_criteria_types_counts.description:
A map of criteria type (for example, `exact`) to the number of rules of that type.

NOTE: The counts in `rule_criteria_types_counts` may be larger than the value of `rule_total_count` because a rule may have multiple criteria.

rule_type_counts.description: A map of rule type (for example, `pinned`) to the number of rules of that type.

rule_id.description: Rule unique identifier within that ruleset

id.description: The search requests ID, used to group result details later.

_index.description: The documents index. For data streams, this should be the documents backing index.

rating.description: The documents relevance with regard to this search request.

ignore_unlabeled.description: Controls how unlabeled documents in the search results are counted. If set to true, unlabeled documents are ignored and neither count as relevant or irrelevant. Set to false (the default), they are treated as irrelevant.

relevant_rating_threshold.description: Sets the rating threshold above which documents are considered to be "relevant".

k.description: Sets the maximum number of documents retrieved per query. This value will act in place of the usual size parameter in the query.

normalize.description: If set to true, this metric will calculate the Normalized DCG.

maximum_relevance.description: The highest relevance grade used in the user-supplied relevance judgments.

metric_score.description: The metric_score in the details section shows the contribution of this query to the global quality metric score

unrated_docs.description: The unrated_docs section contains an _index and _id entry for each document in the search result for this query that didnt have a ratings value. This can be used to ask the user to supply ratings for these documents

hits.description: The hits section shows a grouping of the search results with their supplied ratings

metric_details.description: The metric_details give additional information about the calculated quality metric (e.g. how many of the retrieved documents were relevant). The content varies for each metric but allows for better interpretation of the results

index.description: The name of the data stream, index, or index alias you are copying to.

op_type.description:
If it is `create`, the operation will only index documents that do not already exist (also known as "put if absent").

IMPORTANT: To reindex to a data stream destination, this argument must be `create`.

pipeline.description: The name of the pipeline to use.

routing.description:
By default, a document's routing is preserved unless it's changed by the script.
If it is `keep`, the routing on the bulk request sent for each match is set to the routing on the match.
If it is `discard`, the routing on the bulk request sent for each match is set to `null`.
If it is `=value`, the routing on the bulk request sent for each match is set to all value specified after the equals sign (`=`).

version_type.description: The versioning to use for the indexing operation.

index.description:
The name of the data stream, index, or alias you are copying from.
It accepts a comma-separated list to reindex from multiple sources.

query.description: The documents to reindex, which is defined with Query DSL.

remote.description: A remote instance of Elasticsearch that you want to index from.

size.description:
The number of documents to index per batch.
Use it when you are indexing from remote to ensure that the batches fit within the on-heap buffer, which defaults to a maximum size of 100 MB.

slice.description: Slice the reindex request manually using the provided slice ID and total number of slices.

sort.description:
A comma-separated list of `<field>:<direction>` pairs to sort by before indexing.
Use it in conjunction with `max_docs` to control what documents are reindexed.

WARNING: Sort in reindex is deprecated.
Sorting in reindex was never guaranteed to index documents in order and prevents further development of reindex such as resilience and performance improvements.
If used in combination with `max_docs`, consider using a query filter instead.

_source.description:
If `true`, reindex all source fields.
Set it to a list to reindex select fields.

headers.description: An object containing the headers of the request.

host.description:
The URL for the remote instance of Elasticsearch that you want to index from.
This information is required when you're indexing from remote.

username.description: The username to use for authentication with the remote host (required when using basic auth).

password.description: The password to use for authentication with the remote host (required when using basic auth).

api_key.description:
The API key to use for authentication with the remote host (as an alternative to basic auth when the remote cluster is in Elastic Cloud).
(It is not permitted to set this and also to set an `Authorization` header via `headers`.)

document.description: Document that's temporarily indexed in-memory and accessible from the script.

index.description:
Index containing a mapping that's compatible with the indexed document.
You may specify a remote index by prefixing the index with the remote cluster alias.
For example, `remote1:my_index` indicates that you want to run the painless script against the "my_index" index on the "remote1" cluster.
This request will be forwarded to the "remote1" cluster if you have configured a connection to that remote cluster.

NOTE: Wildcards are not accepted in the index expression for this endpoint.
The expression `*:myindex` will return the error "No such remote cluster" and the expression `logs*` or `remote1:logs*` will return the error "index not found".

query.description: Use this parameter to specify a query for computing a score.

name.description: Search Application name

updated_at_millis.description: Last time the Search Application was updated.

indices.description: Indices that are part of the Search Application.

analytics_collection_name.description: Analytics collection associated to the Search Application.

template.description: Search template to use on search operations.

script.description: The associated mustache template.

name.description: The name of the analytics collection created or updated

cluster.description: A list of cluster privileges. These privileges define the cluster level actions that API keys are able to execute.

indices.description: A list of indices permissions entries.

applications.description: A list of application privilege entries

metadata.description: Optional meta-data. Within the metadata object, keys that begin with `_` are reserved for system usage.

run_as.description:
A list of users that the API keys can impersonate.
NOTE: In Elastic Cloud Serverless, the run-as feature is disabled.
For API compatibility, you can still specify an empty `run_as` field, but a non-empty list will be rejected.

description.description: Optional description of the role descriptor

restriction.description: Restriction for when the role descriptor is allowed to be effective.

field_security.description: The document fields that the owners of the role have read access to.

names.description: A list of indices (or index name patterns) to which the permissions in this entry apply.

privileges.description: The index level privileges that owners of the role have on the specified indices.

query.description: A search query that defines the documents the owners of the role have access to. A document within the specified indices must match this query for it to be accessible by the owners of the role.

security._types.IndicesPrivilegesQuery.description:
While creating or updating a role you can provide either a JSON structure or a string to the API.
However, the response provided by Elasticsearch will only be string with a json-as-text content.

Since this is embedded in `IndicesPrivileges`, the same structure is used for clarity in both contexts.

template.description:
When you create a role, you can specify a query that defines the document level security permissions. You can optionally
use Mustache templates in the role query to insert the username of the current authenticated user into the role.
Like other places in Elasticsearch that support templating or scripting, you can specify inline, stored, or file-based
templates and define custom parameters. You access the details for the current authenticated user through the _user parameter.

id.description: The `id` for a stored script.

params.description:
Specifies any named parameters that are passed into the script as variables.
Use parameters instead of hard-coded values to decrease compile time.

lang.description: Specifies the language the script is written in.

application.description: The name of the application to which this entry applies.

privileges.description: A list of strings, where each element is the name of an application privilege or action.

resources.description: A list resources to which the privileges are applied.

workflows.description:
A list of workflows to which the API key is restricted.
NOTE: In order to use a role restriction, an API key must be created with a single role descriptor.

id.description: Id for the API key

name.description: Name of the API key.

type.description: The type of the API key (e.g. `rest` or `cross_cluster`).

creation.description: Creation time for the API key in milliseconds.

expiration.description: Expiration time for the API key in milliseconds.

invalidated.description:
Invalidation status for the API key.
If the key has been invalidated, it has a value of `true`. Otherwise, it is `false`.

invalidation.description: If the key has been invalidated, invalidation time in milliseconds.

username.description: Principal for which this API key was created

realm.description: Realm name of the principal for which this API key was created.

realm_type.description: Realm type of the principal for which this API key was created

role_descriptors.description:
The role descriptors assigned to this API key when it was created or last updated.
An empty role descriptor means the API key inherits the owner users permissions.

limited_by.description:
The owner users permissions associated with the API key.
It is a point-in-time snapshot captured at creation and subsequent updates.
An API keys effective permissions are an intersection of its assigned privileges and the owner users permissions.

access.description:
The access granted to cross-cluster API keys.
The access is composed of permissions for cross cluster search and cross cluster replication.
At least one of them must be specified.
When specified, the new access assignment fully replaces the previously assigned access.

profile_uid.description: The profile uid for the API key owner principal, if requested and if it exists

_sort.description: Sorting values when using the `sort` parameter with the `security.query_api_keys` API.

replication.description: A list of indices permission entries for cross-cluster replication.

search.description: A list of indices permission entries for cross-cluster search.

names.description: A list of indices (or index name patterns) to which the permissions in this entry apply.

allow_restricted_indices.description: This needs to be set to true if the patterns in the names field should cover system indices.

field_security.description: The document fields that the owners of the role have read access to.

names.description: A list of indices (or index name patterns) to which the permissions in this entry apply.

query.description: A search query that defines the documents the owners of the role have access to. A document within the specified indices must match this query for it to be accessible by the owners of the role.

privileges.description:
A list of the privileges that you want to check for the specified resources.
It may be either application privilege names or the names of actions that are granted by those privileges

resources.description: A list of resource names against which the privileges should be checked.

privileges.description: A list of the privileges that you want to check for the specified indices.

allow_restricted_indices.description:
This needs to be set to `true` (default is `false`) if using wildcards or regexps for patterns that cover restricted indices.
Implicitly, restricted indices do not match index patterns because restricted indices usually have limited privileges and including them in pattern tests would render most such tests false.
If restricted indices are explicitly included in the names list, privileges will be checked against them regardless of the value of `allow_restricted_indices`.

aggregations.description:
Sub-aggregations for this aggregation.
Only applies to bucket aggregations.

cardinality.description: A single-value metrics aggregation that calculates an approximate count of distinct values.

composite.description:
A multi-bucket aggregation that creates composite buckets from different sources.
Unlike the other multi-bucket aggregations, you can use the `composite` aggregation to paginate *all* buckets from a multi-level aggregation efficiently.

date_range.description: A multi-bucket value source based aggregation that enables the user to define a set of date ranges - each representing a bucket.

filter.description: A single bucket aggregation that narrows the set of documents to those that match a query.

filters.description: A multi-bucket aggregation where each bucket contains the documents that match a query.

range.description: A multi-bucket value source based aggregation that enables the user to define a set of ranges - each representing a bucket.

terms.description: A multi-bucket value source based aggregation where buckets are dynamically built - one per unique value.

value_count.description: A single-value metrics aggregation that counts the number of values that are extracted from the aggregated documents.

bool.description: Matches documents matching boolean combinations of other queries.

exists.description: Returns documents that contain an indexed value for a field.

ids.description:
Returns documents based on their IDs.
This query uses document IDs stored in the `_id` field.

match.description:
Returns documents that match a provided text, number, date or boolean value.
The provided text is analyzed before matching.

match_all.description: Matches all documents, giving them all a `_score` of 1.0.

prefix.description: Returns documents that contain a specific prefix in a provided field.

range.description: Returns documents that contain terms within a provided range.

simple_query_string.description: Returns documents based on a provided query string, using a parser with a limited but fault-tolerant syntax.

term.description:
Returns documents that contain an exact term in a provided field.
To return a document, the query term must exactly match the queried field's value, including whitespace and capitalization.

terms.description:
Returns documents that contain one or more exact terms in a provided field.
To return a document, one or more terms must exactly match a field value, including whitespace and capitalization.

wildcard.description: Returns documents that contain terms matching a wildcard pattern.

filters.description: Collection of queries from which to build buckets.

other_bucket.description: Set to `true` to add a bucket to the response which will contain all documents that do not match any of the given filters.

other_bucket_key.description: The key with which the other bucket is returned.

keyed.description:
By default, the named filters aggregation returns the buckets as an object.
Set to `false` to return the buckets as an array of objects.

_types.aggregations.BucketsApiKeyQueryCo.description:
Aggregation buckets. By default they are returned as an array, but if the aggregation has keys configured for
the different buckets, the result is a dictionary.

bool.description: matches roles matching boolean combinations of other queries.

exists.description: Returns roles that contain an indexed value for a field.

ids.description:
Returns roles based on their IDs.
This query uses role document IDs stored in the `_id` field.

match.description:
Returns roles that match a provided text, number, date or boolean value.
The provided text is analyzed before matching.

match_all.description: Matches all roles, giving them all a `_score` of 1.0.

prefix.description: Returns roles that contain a specific prefix in a provided field.

range.description: Returns roles that contain terms within a provided range.

simple_query_string.description: Returns roles based on a provided query string, using a parser with a limited but fault-tolerant syntax.

term.description:
Returns roles that contain an exact term in a provided field.
To return a document, the query term must exactly match the queried field's value, including whitespace and capitalization.

terms.description:
Returns roles that contain one or more exact terms in a provided field.
To return a document, one or more terms must exactly match a field value, including whitespace and capitalization.

wildcard.description: Returns roles that contain terms matching a wildcard pattern.

name.description: Name of the role.

reload_analyzers_details.description:
Updating synonyms in a synonym set can reload the associated analyzers in case refresh is set to true.
This information is the analyzers reloading result.

id.description: Synonym Rule identifier

synonyms.description: Synonyms, in Solr format, that conform the synonym rule.

count.description: Number of synonym rules that the synonym set contains

id.description:
The identifier for the synonym rule.
If you do not specify a synonym rule ID when you create a rule, an identifier is created automatically by Elasticsearch.

synonyms.description: The synonyms that conform the synonym rule in Solr format.

description.description:
Human readable text that identifies the particular request that the task is performing.
For example, it might identify the search request being performed by a search task.
Other kinds of tasks have different descriptions, like `_reindex` which has the source and the destination, or `_bulk` which just has the number of requests and the destination indices.
Many requests will have only an empty description because more detailed information about the request is not easily available or particularly helpful in identifying the request.

status.description:
The internal status of the task, which varies from task to task.
The format also varies.
While the goal is to keep the status for a particular task consistent from version to version, this is not always possible because sometimes the implementation changes.
Fields might be removed from the status for a particular request so any parsing you do of the status might break in minor releases.

authorization.description: The security privileges that the transform uses to run its queries. If Elastic Stack security features were disabled at the time of the most recent update to the transform, this property is omitted.

create_time.description: The time the transform was created.

description.description: Free text description of the transform.

pivot.description: The pivot method transforms the data by aggregating and grouping it.

source.description: The source of the data for the transform.

sync.description: Defines the properties transforms require to run continuously.

version.description: The version of Elasticsearch that existed on the node when the transform was created.

api_key.description: If an API key was used for the most recent update to the transform, its name and identifier are listed in the response.

roles.description: If a user ID was used for the most recent update to the transform, its roles at the time of the update are listed in the response.

service_account.description: If a service account was used for the most recent update to the transform, the account name is listed in the response.

sort.description: Specifies the date field that is used to identify the latest documents.

unique_key.description: Specifies an array of one or more fields that are used to group the data.

aggregations.description:
Defines how to aggregate the grouped data. The following aggregations are currently supported: average, bucket
script, bucket selector, cardinality, filter, geo bounds, geo centroid, geo line, max, median absolute deviation,
min, missing, percentiles, rare terms, scripted metric, stats, sum, terms, top metrics, value count, weighted
average.

group_by.description:
Defines how to group the data. More than one grouping can be defined per pivot. The following groupings are
currently supported: date histogram, geotile grid, histogram, terms.

time.description: Specifies that the transform uses a time field to set the retention policy.

field.description: The date field that is used to calculate the age of the document.

max_age.description:
Specifies the maximum age of a document in the destination index. Documents that are older than the configured
value are removed from the destination index.

transform._types.Settings.description: The source of the data for the transform.

align_checkpoints.description:
Specifies whether the transform checkpoint ranges should be optimized for performance. Such optimization can align
checkpoint ranges with the date histogram interval when date histogram is specified as a group source in the
transform config. As a result, less document updates in the destination index will be performed thus improving
overall performance.

dates_as_epoch_millis.description:
Defines if dates in the ouput should be written as ISO formatted string or as millis since epoch. epoch_millis was
the default for transforms created before version 7.11. For compatible output set this value to `true`.

deduce_mappings.description: Specifies whether the transform should deduce the destination index mappings from the transform configuration.

docs_per_second.description:
Specifies a limit on the number of input documents per second. This setting throttles the transform by adding a
wait time between search requests. The default value is null, which disables throttling.

max_page_search_size.description:
Defines the initial page size to use for the composite aggregation for each checkpoint. If circuit breaker
exceptions occur, the page size is dynamically adjusted to a lower value. The minimum value is `10` and the
maximum is `65,536`.

use_point_in_time.description:
Specifies whether the transform checkpoint will use the Point In Time API while searching over the source index.
In general, Point In Time is an optimization that will reduce pressure on the source index by reducing the amount
of refreshes and merges, but it can be expensive if a large number of Point In Times are opened and closed for a
given index. The benefits and impact depend on the data being searched, the ingest rate into the source index, and
the amount of other consumers searching the same source index.

unattended.description:
If `true`, the transform runs in unattended mode. In unattended mode, the transform retries indefinitely in case
of an error which means the transform never fails. Setting the number of retries other than infinite fails in
validation.

index.description:
The source indices for the transform. It can be a single index, an index pattern (for example, `"my-index-*""`), an
array of indices (for example, `["my-index-000001", "my-index-000002"]`), or an array of index patterns (for
example, `["my-index-*", "my-other-index-*"]`. For remote indices use the syntax `"remote_name:index_name"`. If
any indices are in remote clusters then the master node and at least one transform node must have the `remote_cluster_client` node role.

query.description: A query clause that retrieves a subset of data from the source index.

runtime_mappings.description:
Definitions of search-time runtime fields that can be used by the transform. For search runtime fields all data
nodes, including remote nodes, must be 7.12 or later.

time.description: Specifies that the transform uses a time field to synchronize the source and destination indices.

delay.description: The time delay between the current time and the latest input data time.

field.description:
The date field that is used to identify new documents in the source. In general, its a good idea to use a field
that contains the ingest timestamp. If you use a different field, you might need to set the delay such that it
accounts for data transmission delays.

issues.description: If a non-healthy status is returned, contains a list of issues of the transform.

type.description: The type of the issue

count.description: Number of times this issue has occurred since it started

first_occurrence.description: The timestamp this issue occurred for for the first time

index.description:
The destination index for the transform. The mappings of the destination index are deduced based on the source
fields when possible. If alternate mappings are required, use the create index API prior to starting the
transform.

pipeline.description: The unique identifier for an ingest pipeline.

AsyncSearchSubmitResponseExample1.description: A successful response when performing search asynchronously.

errors.description: If `true`, one or more of the operations in the bulk request did not complete successfully.

items.description: The result of each operation in the bulk request, in the order they were submitted.

took.description: The length of time, in milliseconds, it took to process the bulk request.

BulkResponseExample2.description: If you run `POST /_bulk` with operations that update non-existent documents, the operations cannot complete successfully. The API returns a response with an `errors` property value `true`. The response also includes an error object for any failed operations. The error object contains additional information about the failure, such as the error type and reason.

BulkResponseExample3.description: An example response from `POST /_bulk?filter_path=items.*.error`, which returns only information about failed operations.

CatAliasesResponseExample1.description: A successful response from `GET _cat/aliases?format=json&v=true`. This response shows that `alias2` has configured a filter and `alias3` and `alias4` have routing configurations.

CatCountResponseExample1.summary: Single data stream or index count
CatCountResponseExample1.description: A successful response from `GET /_cat/count/my-index-000001?v=true&format=json`. It retrieves the document count for the `my-index-000001` data stream or index.

CatCountResponseExample2.summary: All data streams and indices count
CatCountResponseExample2.description: A successful response from `GET /_cat/count?v=true&format=json`. It retrieves the document count for all data streams and indices in the cluster.

succeeded.description:
If `true`, the request succeeded.
This does not indicate whether any scrolling search requests were cleared.

num_freed.description: The number of scrolling search requests cleared.

GetComponentTemplateResponseExample1.description: A successful response for retrieving information about a component template.

CreateResponseExample1.description: A successful response from `PUT my-index-000001/_create/1` which indexes a document.

EqlSearchResponseExample2.summary: A successful response for performing search with an EQL query.

indices.description: The list of indices where this field has the same type family, or null if all indices have the same type family for the field.

FieldCapabilitiesResponseExample1.description: A successful response from `GET _field_caps?fields=rating,title`. The field `rating` is defined as a long in `index1` and `index2` and as a `keyword` in `index3` and `index4`. The field `rating` is not aggregatable in `index1`. The field `rating` is not searchable in `index4`. The field `title` is defined as text in all indices.

FieldCapabilitiesResponseExample2.description: A successful response from `GET _field_caps?fields=rating,title&include_unmapped`. The response contains an entry for each field that is present in some indices but not all. For example, the `rating` and `title` fields are unmapped in `index5`.

IndexResponseExample1.description: A successful response from `POST my-index-000001/_doc/`, which contains an automated document ID.

indicesAnalyzeResponseExample7.description: A successful response for an analysis with `explain` set to `true`.

indicesGetDataStreamResponseExample1.description: A successful response for retrieving information about a data stream.

GetIndexTemplateResponseExample1.description: A successful response for retrieving information about an index template.

indicesSimulateTemplateResponseExample2.description: A successful response from `POST /_index_template/_simulate` with a template configuration in the request body. The response shows any overlapping templates with a lower priority.

GetPipelineResponseExample1.description: A successful response for retrieving information about an ingest pipeline.

SimulatePipelineResponseExample1.description: A successful response for running an ingest pipeline against a set of provided documents.

docs.description:
The response includes a docs array that contains the documents in the order specified in the request.
The structure of the returned documents is similar to that returned by the get API.
If there is a failure getting a particular document, the error is included in place of the document.

data_frame_analytics.description: An array of data frame analytics job resources, which are sorted by the id value in ascending order.
An array of objects that contain usage information for data frame analytics jobs, which are sorted by the id value in ascending order.

trained_model_configs.description: An array of trained model resources, which are sorted by the model_id value in ascending order.

count.description: The total number of trained model statistics that matched the requested ID patterns. Could be higher than the number of items in the trained_model_stats array as the size of the array is restricted by the supplied size parameter.

trained_model_stats.description: An array of trained model statistics, which are sorted by the model_id value in ascending order.

feature_values.description: An array of objects that contain feature name and value pairs. The features have been processed and indicate what will be sent to the model for training.

metric_score.description: The overall evaluation quality calculated by the defined metric

details.description: The details section contains one entry for every query in the original requests section, keyed by the search request id

ExecutePainlessScriptResponseExample1.description: A successful response from `POST /_scripts/painless/_execute` with a `painless_test` context.

ExecutePainlessScriptResponseExample2.description: A successful response from `POST /_scripts/painless/_execute` with a `filter` context.

ExecutePainlessScriptResponseExample3.description: A successful response from `POST /_scripts/painless/_execute` with a `score` context.

SearchResponseExample1.description: An abbreviated response from `GET /my-index-000001/_search?from=40&size=20` with a simple term query.

SearchMvtResponseExample1.description: A successful response from `GET museums/_mvt/location/13/4207/2692`. It returns results as a binary vector tile. When decoded into JSON, the tile contains the following data.

api_key.description: Generated API key.

expiration.description: Expiration in milliseconds for the API key.

id.description: Unique ID for this API key.

name.description: Specifies the name for this API key.

encoded.description:
API key credentials which is the base64-encoding of
the UTF-8 representation of `id` and `api_key` joined
by a colon (`:`).

SecurityGetRoleResponseExample1.description: A successful response from `GET /_security/role/my_admin_role`. The response contains information about the `my_admin_role` role in the native realm.

SecurityHasPrivilegesResponseExample1.description: A successful response from `GET /_security/user/_has_privileges`, which lists the privileges for the `rdeniro` user.

role.description: When an existing role is updated, `created` is set to `false`.

total.description: The total number of API keys found.

count.description: The number of API keys returned in the response.

api_keys.description: A list of API key information.

QueryApiKeysResponseExample1.description: A successful response from `GET /_security/_query/api_key?with_limited_by=true`. The `limited_by` details are the owner user's permissions associated with the API key. It is a point-in-time snapshot captured at creation and subsequent updates. An API key's effective permissions are an intersection of its assigned privileges and the owner user's permissions.

QueryApiKeysResponseExample2.description: An abbreviated response from `GET /_security/_query/api_key` that contains a list of matched API keys along with their sort values. The first sort value is creation time, which is displayed in `date_time` format. The second sort value is the API key name.

QueryApiKeysResponseExample3.description: A successful response from `GET /_security/_query/api_key`. It includes the role descriptors that are assigned to each API key when it was created or last updated. Note that an API key's effective permissions are an intersection of its assigned privileges and the point-in-time snapshot of the owner user's permissions. An empty role descriptors object means the API key inherits the owner user's permissions.

total.description: The total number of roles found.

count.description: The number of roles returned in the response.

roles.description:
A list of roles that match the query.
The returned role format is an extension of the role definition format.
It adds the `transient_metadata.enabled` and the `_sort` fields.
`transient_metadata.enabled` is set to `false` in case the role is automatically disabled, for example when the role grants privileges that are not allowed by the installed license.
`_sort` is present when the search query sorts on some field.
It contains the array of values that have been used for sorting.

QueryRolesResponseExample1.description: A successful response from `POST /_security/_query/role`. It returns a JSON structure that contains the information retrieved for one or more roles.

columns.description: Column headings for the search results. Each object is a column.

cursor.description:
The cursor for the next set of paginated results.
For CSV, TSV, and TXT responses, this value is returned in the `Cursor` HTTP header.

id.description:
The identifier for the search.
This value is returned only for async and saved synchronous searches.
For CSV, TSV, and TXT responses, this value is returned in the `Async-ID` HTTP header.

is_running.description:
If `true`, the search is still running.
If `false`, the search has finished.
This value is returned only for async and saved synchronous searches.
For CSV, TSV, and TXT responses, this value is returned in the `Async-partial` HTTP header.

is_partial.description:
If `true`, the response does not contain complete search results.
If `is_partial` is `true` and `is_running` is `true`, the search is still running.
If `is_partial` is `true` but `is_running` is `false`, the results are partial due to a failure or timeout.
This value is returned only for async and saved synchronous searches.
For CSV, TSV, and TXT responses, this value is returned in the `Async-partial` HTTP header.

rows.description: The values for the search results.

complete.description:
If `false`, the returned terms set may be incomplete and should be treated as approximate.
This can occur due to a few reasons, such as a request timeout or a node error.

TermVectorsResponseExample2.description: A successful response from `GET /my-index-000001/_termvectors` with `per_field_analyzer` in the request body.

TermVectorsResponseExample3.description: A successful response from `GET /my-index-000001/_termvectors` with a `filter` in the request body.

GetTransformResponseExample1.description: A successful response that contains configuration information for a transform.

PreviewTransformResponseExample1.description: An abbreviated response from `POST _transform/_preview` that contains a preview a transform that uses the pivot method.

async_search.submit-index.name: index
async_search.submit-index.description: A comma-separated list of index names to search; use `_all` or empty string to perform the operation on all indices

async_search.submit-wait_for_completion_.name: wait_for_completion_timeout
async_search.submit-wait_for_completion_.description:
Blocks and waits until the search is completed up to a certain timeout.
When the async search completes within the timeout, the response wont include the ID as the results are not stored in the cluster.

async_search.submit-keep_alive.name: keep_alive
async_search.submit-keep_alive.description:
Specifies how long the async search needs to be available.
Ongoing async searches and any saved search results are deleted after this period.

async_search.submit-keep_on_completion.name: keep_on_completion
async_search.submit-keep_on_completion.description: If `true`, results are stored for later retrieval when the search completes within the `wait_for_completion_timeout`.

async_search.submit-allow_no_indices.name: allow_no_indices
async_search.submit-allow_no_indices.description:
Whether to ignore if a wildcard indices expression resolves into no concrete indices.
(This includes `_all` string or when no indices have been specified)

async_search.submit-allow_partial_search.name: allow_partial_search_results
async_search.submit-allow_partial_search.description: Indicate if an error should be returned if there is a partial search failure or timeout

async_search.submit-analyzer.name: analyzer
async_search.submit-analyzer.description: The analyzer to use for the query string

async_search.submit-analyze_wildcard.name: analyze_wildcard
async_search.submit-analyze_wildcard.description: Specify whether wildcard and prefix queries should be analyzed

async_search.submit-batched_reduce_size.name: batched_reduce_size
async_search.submit-batched_reduce_size.description:
Affects how often partial results become available, which happens whenever shard results are reduced.
A partial reduction is performed every time the coordinating node has received a certain number of new shard responses (5 by default).

async_search.submit-ccs_minimize_roundtr.name: ccs_minimize_roundtrips
async_search.submit-ccs_minimize_roundtr.description: The default value is the only supported value.

async_search.submit-default_operator.name: default_operator
async_search.submit-default_operator.description: The default operator for query string query (AND or OR)

async_search.submit-df.name: df
async_search.submit-df.description: The field to use as default where no field prefix is given in the query string

async_search.submit-docvalue_fields.name: docvalue_fields
async_search.submit-docvalue_fields.description: A comma-separated list of fields to return as the docvalue representation of a field for each hit

async_search.submit-expand_wildcards.name: expand_wildcards
async_search.submit-expand_wildcards.description: Whether to expand wildcard expression to concrete indices that are open, closed or both

async_search.submit-explain.name: explain
async_search.submit-explain.description: Specify whether to return detailed information about score computation as part of a hit

async_search.submit-ignore_throttled.name: ignore_throttled
async_search.submit-ignore_throttled.description: Whether specified concrete, expanded or aliased indices should be ignored when throttled

async_search.submit-ignore_unavailable.name: ignore_unavailable
async_search.submit-ignore_unavailable.description: Whether specified concrete indices should be ignored when unavailable (missing or closed)

async_search.submit-lenient.name: lenient
async_search.submit-lenient.description: Specify whether format-based query failures (such as providing text to a numeric field) should be ignored

async_search.submit-max_concurrent_shard.name: max_concurrent_shard_requests
async_search.submit-max_concurrent_shard.description:
The number of concurrent shard requests per node this search executes concurrently.
This value should be used to limit the impact of the search on the cluster in order to limit the number of concurrent shard requests

async_search.submit-preference.name: preference
async_search.submit-preference.description: Specify the node or shard the operation should be performed on

async_search.submit-request_cache.name: request_cache
async_search.submit-request_cache.description: Specify if request cache should be used for this request or not, defaults to true

async_search.submit-routing.name: routing
async_search.submit-routing.description: A comma-separated list of specific routing values

async_search.submit-stats.name: stats
async_search.submit-stats.description: Specific 'tag' of the request for logging and statistical purposes

async_search.submit-stored_fields.name: stored_fields
async_search.submit-stored_fields.description: A comma-separated list of stored fields to return as part of a hit

async_search.submit-suggest_field.name: suggest_field
async_search.submit-suggest_field.description: Specifies which field to use for suggestions.

async_search.submit-suggest_size.name: suggest_size
async_search.submit-suggest_size.description: How many suggestions to return in response

async_search.submit-suggest_text.name: suggest_text
async_search.submit-suggest_text.description: The source text for which the suggestions should be returned.

async_search.submit-terminate_after.name: terminate_after
async_search.submit-terminate_after.description: The maximum number of documents to collect for each shard, upon reaching which the query execution will terminate early

async_search.submit-track_total_hits.name: track_total_hits
async_search.submit-track_total_hits.description:
Indicate if the number of documents that match the query should be tracked.
A number can also be specified, to accurately track the total hit count up to the number.

async_search.submit-track_scores.name: track_scores
async_search.submit-track_scores.description: Whether to calculate and return scores even if they are not used for sorting

async_search.submit-typed_keys.name: typed_keys
async_search.submit-typed_keys.description: Specify whether aggregation and suggester names should be prefixed by their respective types in the response

async_search.submit-rest_total_hits_as_i.name: rest_total_hits_as_int
async_search.submit-rest_total_hits_as_i.description: Indicates whether hits.total should be rendered as an integer or an object in the rest search response

async_search.submit-version.name: version
async_search.submit-version.description: Specify whether to return document version as part of a hit

async_search.submit-_source.name: _source
async_search.submit-_source.description: True or false to return the _source field or not, or a list of fields to return

async_search.submit-_source_excludes.name: _source_excludes
async_search.submit-_source_excludes.description: A list of fields to exclude from the returned _source field

async_search.submit-_source_includes.name: _source_includes
async_search.submit-_source_includes.description: A list of fields to extract and return from the _source field

async_search.submit-seq_no_primary_term.name: seq_no_primary_term
async_search.submit-seq_no_primary_term.description: Specify whether to return sequence number and primary term of the last modification of each hit

async_search.submit-q.name: q
async_search.submit-q.description: Query in the Lucene query string syntax

bulk-index.name: index
bulk-index.description: The name of the data stream, index, or index alias to perform bulk actions on.

bulk-include_source_on_error.name: include_source_on_error
bulk-include_source_on_error.description: True or false if to include the document source in the error message in case of parsing errors.

bulk-list_executed_pipelines.name: list_executed_pipelines
bulk-list_executed_pipelines.description: If `true`, the response will include the ingest pipelines that were run for each index or create.

bulk-pipeline.name: pipeline
bulk-pipeline.description:
The pipeline identifier to use to preprocess incoming documents.
If the index has a default ingest pipeline specified, setting the value to `_none` turns off the default ingest pipeline for this request.
If a final pipeline is configured, it will always run regardless of the value of this parameter.

bulk-refresh.name: refresh
bulk-refresh.description:
If `true`, Elasticsearch refreshes the affected shards to make this operation visible to search.
If `wait_for`, wait for a refresh to make this operation visible to search.
If `false`, do nothing with refreshes.
Valid values: `true`, `false`, `wait_for`.

bulk-routing.name: routing
bulk-routing.description: A custom value that is used to route operations to a specific shard.

bulk-_source.name: _source
bulk-_source.description: Indicates whether to return the `_source` field (`true` or `false`) or contains a list of fields to return.

bulk-_source_excludes.name: _source_excludes
bulk-_source_excludes.description:
A comma-separated list of source fields to exclude from the response.
You can also use this parameter to exclude fields from the subset specified in `_source_includes` query parameter.
If the `_source` parameter is `false`, this parameter is ignored.

bulk-_source_includes.name: _source_includes
bulk-_source_includes.description:
A comma-separated list of source fields to include in the response.
If this parameter is specified, only these source fields are returned.
You can exclude fields from this subset using the `_source_excludes` query parameter.
If the `_source` parameter is `false`, this parameter is ignored.

bulk-timeout.name: timeout
bulk-timeout.description:
The period each action waits for the following operations: automatic index creation, dynamic mapping updates, and waiting for active shards.
The default is `1m` (one minute), which guarantees Elasticsearch waits for at least the timeout before failing.
The actual wait time could be longer, particularly when multiple waits occur.

bulk-wait_for_active_shards.name: wait_for_active_shards
bulk-wait_for_active_shards.description:
The number of shard copies that must be active before proceeding with the operation.
Set to `all` or any positive integer up to the total number of shards in the index (`number_of_replicas+1`).
The default is `1`, which waits for each primary shard to be active.

bulk-require_alias.name: require_alias
bulk-require_alias.description: If `true`, the request's actions must target an index alias.

bulk-require_data_stream.name: require_data_stream
bulk-require_data_stream.description: If `true`, the request's actions must target a data stream (existing or to be created).

cat.aliases-name.name: name
cat.aliases-name.description: A comma-separated list of aliases to retrieve. Supports wildcards (`*`).  To retrieve all aliases, omit this parameter or use `*` or `_all`.

cat.aliases-h.name: h
cat.aliases-h.description: A comma-separated list of columns names to display. It supports simple wildcards.

cat.aliases-s.name: s
cat.aliases-s.description:
List of columns that determine how the table should be sorted.
Sorting defaults to ascending and can be changed by setting `:asc`
or `:desc` as a suffix to the column name.

cat.aliases-expand_wildcards.name: expand_wildcards
cat.aliases-expand_wildcards.description:
The type of index that wildcard patterns can match.
If the request can target data streams, this argument determines whether wildcard expressions match hidden data streams.
It supports comma-separated values, such as `open,hidden`.

cat.aliases-master_timeout.name: master_timeout
cat.aliases-master_timeout.description:
The period to wait for a connection to the master node.
If the master node is not available before the timeout expires, the request fails and returns an error.
To indicated that the request should never timeout, you can set it to `-1`.

cat.component_templates-name.name: name
cat.component_templates-name.description:
The name of the component template.
It accepts wildcard expressions.
If it is omitted, all component templates are returned.

cat.component_templates-h.name: h
cat.component_templates-h.description: A comma-separated list of columns names to display. It supports simple wildcards.

cat.component_templates-s.name: s
cat.component_templates-s.description:
List of columns that determine how the table should be sorted.
Sorting defaults to ascending and can be changed by setting `:asc`
or `:desc` as a suffix to the column name.

cat.component_templates-local.name: local
cat.component_templates-local.description:
If `true`, the request computes the list of selected nodes from the
local cluster state. If `false` the list of selected nodes are computed
from the cluster state of the master node. In both cases the coordinating
node will send requests for further information to each selected node.

cat.component_templates-master_timeout.name: master_timeout
cat.component_templates-master_timeout.description: The period to wait for a connection to the master node.

cat.count-index.name: index
cat.count-index.description:
A comma-separated list of data streams, indices, and aliases used to limit the request.
It supports wildcards (`*`).
To target all data streams and indices, omit this parameter or use `*` or `_all`.

cat.count-h.name: h
cat.count-h.description: A comma-separated list of columns names to display. It supports simple wildcards.

cat.count-s.name: s
cat.count-s.description:
List of columns that determine how the table should be sorted.
Sorting defaults to ascending and can be changed by setting `:asc`
or `:desc` as a suffix to the column name.

cat.indices-index.name: index
cat.indices-index.description:
Comma-separated list of data streams, indices, and aliases used to limit the request.
Supports wildcards (`*`). To target all data streams and indices, omit this parameter or use `*` or `_all`.

cat.indices-expand_wildcards.name: expand_wildcards
cat.indices-expand_wildcards.description: The type of index that wildcard patterns can match.

cat.indices-health.name: health
cat.indices-health.description: The health status used to limit returned indices. By default, the response includes indices of any health status.

cat.indices-include_unloaded_segments.name: include_unloaded_segments
cat.indices-include_unloaded_segments.description: If true, the response includes information from segments that are not loaded into memory.

cat.indices-pri.name: pri
cat.indices-pri.description: If true, the response only includes information from primary shards.

cat.indices-master_timeout.name: master_timeout
cat.indices-master_timeout.description: Period to wait for a connection to the master node.

cat.indices-h.name: h
cat.indices-h.description: A comma-separated list of columns names to display. It supports simple wildcards.

cat.indices-s.name: s
cat.indices-s.description:
List of columns that determine how the table should be sorted.
Sorting defaults to ascending and can be changed by setting `:asc`
or `:desc` as a suffix to the column name.

cat.ml_data_frame_analytics-id.name: id
cat.ml_data_frame_analytics-id.description: The ID of the data frame analytics to fetch

cat.ml_data_frame_analytics-allow_no_mat.name: allow_no_match
cat.ml_data_frame_analytics-allow_no_mat.description:
Whether to ignore if a wildcard expression matches no configs.
(This includes `_all` string or when no configs have been specified.)

cat.ml_data_frame_analytics-h.name: h
cat.ml_data_frame_analytics-h.description: Comma-separated list of column names to display.

cat.ml_data_frame_analytics-s.name: s
cat.ml_data_frame_analytics-s.description:
Comma-separated list of column names or column aliases used to sort the
response.

cat.ml_datafeeds-datafeed_id.name: datafeed_id
cat.ml_datafeeds-datafeed_id.description: A numerical character string that uniquely identifies the datafeed.

cat.ml_datafeeds-allow_no_match.name: allow_no_match
cat.ml_datafeeds-allow_no_match.description:
Specifies what to do when the request:

* Contains wildcard expressions and there are no datafeeds that match.
* Contains the `_all` string or no identifiers and there are no matches.
* Contains wildcard expressions and there are only partial matches.

If `true`, the API returns an empty datafeeds array when there are no matches and the subset of results when
there are partial matches. If `false`, the API returns a 404 status code when there are no matches or only
partial matches.

cat.ml_datafeeds-h.name: h
cat.ml_datafeeds-h.description: Comma-separated list of column names to display.

cat.ml_datafeeds-s.name: s
cat.ml_datafeeds-s.description: Comma-separated list of column names or column aliases used to sort the response.

cat.ml_jobs-job_id.name: job_id
cat.ml_jobs-job_id.description: Identifier for the anomaly detection job.

cat.ml_jobs-allow_no_match.name: allow_no_match
cat.ml_jobs-allow_no_match.description:
Specifies what to do when the request:

* Contains wildcard expressions and there are no jobs that match.
* Contains the `_all` string or no identifiers and there are no matches.
* Contains wildcard expressions and there are only partial matches.

If `true`, the API returns an empty jobs array when there are no matches and the subset of results when there
are partial matches. If `false`, the API returns a 404 status code when there are no matches or only partial
matches.

cat.ml_jobs-h.name: h
cat.ml_jobs-h.description: Comma-separated list of column names to display.

cat.ml_jobs-s.name: s
cat.ml_jobs-s.description: Comma-separated list of column names or column aliases used to sort the response.

cat.ml_trained_models-model_id.name: model_id
cat.ml_trained_models-model_id.description: A unique identifier for the trained model.

cat.ml_trained_models-allow_no_match.name: allow_no_match
cat.ml_trained_models-allow_no_match.description:
Specifies what to do when the request: contains wildcard expressions and there are no models that match; contains the `_all` string or no identifiers and there are no matches; contains wildcard expressions and there are only partial matches.
If `true`, the API returns an empty array when there are no matches and the subset of results when there are partial matches.
If `false`, the API returns a 404 status code when there are no matches or only partial matches.

cat.ml_trained_models-h.name: h
cat.ml_trained_models-h.description: A comma-separated list of column names to display.

cat.ml_trained_models-s.name: s
cat.ml_trained_models-s.description: A comma-separated list of column names or aliases used to sort the response.

cat.ml_trained_models-from.name: from
cat.ml_trained_models-from.description: Skips the specified number of transforms.

cat.ml_trained_models-size.name: size
cat.ml_trained_models-size.description: The maximum number of transforms to display.

cat.transforms-transform_id.name: transform_id
cat.transforms-transform_id.description:
A transform identifier or a wildcard expression.
If you do not specify one of these options, the API returns information for all transforms.

cat.transforms-allow_no_match.name: allow_no_match
cat.transforms-allow_no_match.description:
Specifies what to do when the request: contains wildcard expressions and there are no transforms that match; contains the `_all` string or no identifiers and there are no matches; contains wildcard expressions and there are only partial matches.
If `true`, it returns an empty transforms array when there are no matches and the subset of results when there are partial matches.
If `false`, the request returns a 404 status code when there are no matches or only partial matches.

cat.transforms-from.name: from
cat.transforms-from.description: Skips the specified number of transforms.

cat.transforms-h.name: h
cat.transforms-h.description: Comma-separated list of column names to display.

cat.transforms-s.name: s
cat.transforms-s.description: Comma-separated list of column names or column aliases used to sort the response.

cat.transforms-size.name: size
cat.transforms-size.description: The maximum number of transforms to obtain.

clear_scroll-scroll_id.name: scroll_id
clear_scroll-scroll_id.description:
A comma-separated list of scroll IDs to clear.
To clear all scroll IDs, use `_all`.
IMPORTANT: Scroll IDs can be long. It is recommended to specify scroll IDs in the request body parameter.

cluster.get_component_template-name.name: name
cluster.get_component_template-name.description:
Comma-separated list of component template names used to limit the request.
Wildcard (`*`) expressions are supported.

cluster.get_component_template-flat_sett.name: flat_settings
cluster.get_component_template-flat_sett.description: If `true`, returns settings in flat format.

cluster.get_component_template-settings_.name: settings_filter
cluster.get_component_template-settings_.description: Filter out results, for example to filter out sensitive information. Supports wildcards or full settings keys

cluster.get_component_template-include_d.name: include_defaults
cluster.get_component_template-include_d.description: Return all default configurations for the component template

cluster.get_component_template-local.name: local
cluster.get_component_template-local.description:
If `true`, the request retrieves information from the local node only.
If `false`, information is retrieved from the master node.

cluster.get_component_template-master_ti.name: master_timeout
cluster.get_component_template-master_ti.description:
Period to wait for a connection to the master node.
If no response is received before the timeout expires, the request fails and returns an error.

cluster.put_component_template-name.name: name
cluster.put_component_template-name.description:
Name of the component template to create.
Elasticsearch includes the following built-in component templates: `logs-mappings`; `logs-settings`; `metrics-mappings`; `metrics-settings`;`synthetics-mapping`; `synthetics-settings`.
Elastic Agent uses these templates to configure backing indices for its data streams.
If you use Elastic Agent and want to overwrite one of these templates, set the `version` for your replacement template higher than the current version.
If you dont use Elastic Agent and want to disable all built-in component and index templates, set `stack.templates.enabled` to `false` using the cluster update settings API.

cluster.put_component_template-create.name: create
cluster.put_component_template-create.description: If `true`, this request cannot replace or update existing component templates.

cluster.put_component_template-cause.name: cause
cluster.put_component_template-cause.description: User defined reason for create the component template.

cluster.put_component_template-master_ti.name: master_timeout
cluster.put_component_template-master_ti.description:
Period to wait for a connection to the master node.
If no response is received before the timeout expires, the request fails and returns an error.

connector.put-connector_id.name: connector_id
connector.put-connector_id.description: The unique identifier of the connector to be created or updated. ID is auto-generated if not provided.

count-index.name: index
count-index.description:
A comma-separated list of data streams, indices, and aliases to search.
It supports wildcards (`*`).
To search all data streams and indices, omit this parameter or use `*` or `_all`.

count-allow_no_indices.name: allow_no_indices
count-allow_no_indices.description:
If `false`, the request returns an error if any wildcard expression, index alias, or `_all` value targets only missing or closed indices.
This behavior applies even if the request targets other open indices.
For example, a request targeting `foo*,bar*` returns an error if an index starts with `foo` but no index starts with `bar`.

count-analyzer.name: analyzer
count-analyzer.description:
The analyzer to use for the query string.
This parameter can be used only when the `q` query string parameter is specified.

count-analyze_wildcard.name: analyze_wildcard
count-analyze_wildcard.description:
If `true`, wildcard and prefix queries are analyzed.
This parameter can be used only when the `q` query string parameter is specified.

count-default_operator.name: default_operator
count-default_operator.description:
The default operator for query string query: `and` or `or`.
This parameter can be used only when the `q` query string parameter is specified.

count-df.name: df
count-df.description:
The field to use as a default when no field prefix is given in the query string.
This parameter can be used only when the `q` query string parameter is specified.

count-expand_wildcards.name: expand_wildcards
count-expand_wildcards.description:
The type of index that wildcard patterns can match.
If the request can target data streams, this argument determines whether wildcard expressions match hidden data streams.
It supports comma-separated values, such as `open,hidden`.

count-ignore_throttled.name: ignore_throttled
count-ignore_throttled.description: If `true`, concrete, expanded, or aliased indices are ignored when frozen.

count-ignore_unavailable.name: ignore_unavailable
count-ignore_unavailable.description: If `false`, the request returns an error if it targets a missing or closed index.

count-lenient.name: lenient
count-lenient.description:
If `true`, format-based query failures (such as providing text to a numeric field) in the query string will be ignored.
This parameter can be used only when the `q` query string parameter is specified.

count-min_score.name: min_score
count-min_score.description: The minimum `_score` value that documents must have to be included in the result.

count-preference.name: preference
count-preference.description:
The node or shard the operation should be performed on.
By default, it is random.

count-routing.name: routing
count-routing.description: A custom value used to route operations to a specific shard.

count-terminate_after.name: terminate_after
count-terminate_after.description:
The maximum number of documents to collect for each shard.
If a query reaches this limit, Elasticsearch terminates the query early.
Elasticsearch collects documents before sorting.

IMPORTANT: Use with caution.
Elasticsearch applies this parameter to each shard handling the request.
When possible, let Elasticsearch perform early termination automatically.
Avoid specifying this parameter for requests that target data streams with backing indices across multiple data tiers.

count-q.name: q
count-q.description: The query in Lucene query string syntax. This parameter cannot be used with a request body.

create-id.name: id
create-id.description:
A unique identifier for the document.
To automatically generate a document ID, use the `POST /<target>/_doc/` request format.

create-index.name: index
create-index.description:
The name of the data stream or index to target.
If the target doesn't exist and matches the name or wildcard (`*`) pattern of an index template with a `data_stream` definition, this request creates the data stream.
If the target doesn't exist and doesnt match a data stream template, this request creates the index.

create-include_source_on_error.name: include_source_on_error
create-include_source_on_error.description: True or false if to include the document source in the error message in case of parsing errors.

create-pipeline.name: pipeline
create-pipeline.description:
The ID of the pipeline to use to preprocess incoming documents.
If the index has a default ingest pipeline specified, setting the value to `_none` turns off the default ingest pipeline for this request.
If a final pipeline is configured, it will always run regardless of the value of this parameter.

create-refresh.name: refresh
create-refresh.description:
If `true`, Elasticsearch refreshes the affected shards to make this operation visible to search.
If `wait_for`, it waits for a refresh to make this operation visible to search.
If `false`, it does nothing with refreshes.

create-require_alias.name: require_alias
create-require_alias.description: If `true`, the destination must be an index alias.

create-require_data_stream.name: require_data_stream
create-require_data_stream.description: If `true`, the request's actions must target a data stream (existing or to be created).

create-routing.name: routing
create-routing.description: A custom value that is used to route operations to a specific shard.

create-timeout.name: timeout
create-timeout.description:
The period the request waits for the following operations: automatic index creation, dynamic mapping updates, waiting for active shards.
Elasticsearch waits for at least the specified timeout period before failing.
The actual wait time could be longer, particularly when multiple waits occur.

This parameter is useful for situations where the primary shard assigned to perform the operation might not be available when the operation runs.
Some reasons for this might be that the primary shard is currently recovering from a gateway or undergoing relocation.
By default, the operation will wait on the primary shard to become available for at least 1 minute before failing and responding with an error.
The actual wait time could be longer, particularly when multiple waits occur.

create-version.name: version
create-version.description:
The explicit version number for concurrency control.
It must be a non-negative long number.

create-wait_for_active_shards.name: wait_for_active_shards
create-wait_for_active_shards.description:
The number of shard copies that must be active before proceeding with the operation.
You can set it to `all` or any positive integer up to the total number of shards in the index (`number_of_replicas+1`).
The default value of `1` means it waits for each primary shard to be active.

enrich.get_policy-name.name: name
enrich.get_policy-name.description:
Comma-separated list of enrich policy names used to limit the request.
To return information for all enrich policies, omit this parameter.

enrich.get_policy-master_timeout.name: master_timeout
enrich.get_policy-master_timeout.description: Period to wait for a connection to the master node.

eql.search-index.name: index
eql.search-index.description: Comma-separated list of index names to scope the operation

eql.search-allow_no_indices.name: allow_no_indices
eql.search-allow_no_indices.description:
Whether to ignore if a wildcard indices expression resolves into no concrete indices.
(This includes `_all` string or when no indices have been specified)

eql.search-allow_partial_search_results.name: allow_partial_search_results
eql.search-allow_partial_search_results.description: If true, returns partial results if there are shard failures. If false, returns an error with no partial results.

eql.search-allow_partial_sequence_result.name: allow_partial_sequence_results
eql.search-allow_partial_sequence_result.description:
If true, sequence queries will return partial results in case of shard failures. If false, they will return no results at all.
This flag has effect only if allow_partial_search_results is true.

eql.search-expand_wildcards.name: expand_wildcards
eql.search-expand_wildcards.description: Whether to expand wildcard expression to concrete indices that are open, closed or both.

eql.search-ccs_minimize_roundtrips.name: ccs_minimize_roundtrips
eql.search-ccs_minimize_roundtrips.description: Indicates whether network round-trips should be minimized as part of cross-cluster search requests execution

eql.search-ignore_unavailable.name: ignore_unavailable
eql.search-ignore_unavailable.description: If true, missing or closed indices are not included in the response.

eql.search-keep_alive.name: keep_alive
eql.search-keep_alive.description: Period for which the search and its results are stored on the cluster.

eql.search-keep_on_completion.name: keep_on_completion
eql.search-keep_on_completion.description: If true, the search and its results are stored on the cluster.

eql.search-wait_for_completion_timeout.name: wait_for_completion_timeout
eql.search-wait_for_completion_timeout.description: Timeout duration to wait for the request to finish. Defaults to no timeout, meaning the request waits for complete search results.

explain-index.name: index
explain-index.description:
Index names that are used to limit the request.
Only a single index name can be provided to this parameter.

explain-analyzer.name: analyzer
explain-analyzer.description:
The analyzer to use for the query string.
This parameter can be used only when the `q` query string parameter is specified.

explain-analyze_wildcard.name: analyze_wildcard
explain-analyze_wildcard.description:
If `true`, wildcard and prefix queries are analyzed.
This parameter can be used only when the `q` query string parameter is specified.

explain-default_operator.name: default_operator
explain-default_operator.description:
The default operator for query string query: `and` or `or`.
This parameter can be used only when the `q` query string parameter is specified.

explain-df.name: df
explain-df.description:
The field to use as default where no field prefix is given in the query string.
This parameter can be used only when the `q` query string parameter is specified.

explain-lenient.name: lenient
explain-lenient.description:
If `true`, format-based query failures (such as providing text to a numeric field) in the query string will be ignored.
This parameter can be used only when the `q` query string parameter is specified.

explain-preference.name: preference
explain-preference.description:
The node or shard the operation should be performed on.
It is random by default.

explain-routing.name: routing
explain-routing.description: A custom value used to route operations to a specific shard.

explain-_source.name: _source
explain-_source.description: `True` or `false` to return the `_source` field or not or a list of fields to return.

explain-_source_excludes.name: _source_excludes
explain-_source_excludes.description:
A comma-separated list of source fields to exclude from the response.
You can also use this parameter to exclude fields from the subset specified in `_source_includes` query parameter.
If the `_source` parameter is `false`, this parameter is ignored.

explain-_source_includes.name: _source_includes
explain-_source_includes.description:
A comma-separated list of source fields to include in the response.
If this parameter is specified, only these source fields are returned.
You can exclude fields from this subset using the `_source_excludes` query parameter.
If the `_source` parameter is `false`, this parameter is ignored.

explain-stored_fields.name: stored_fields
explain-stored_fields.description: A comma-separated list of stored fields to return in the response.

explain-q.name: q
explain-q.description: The query in the Lucene query string syntax.

field_caps-index.name: index
field_caps-index.description: A comma-separated list of data streams, indices, and aliases used to limit the request. Supports wildcards (*). To target all data streams and indices, omit this parameter or use * or _all.

field_caps-allow_no_indices.name: allow_no_indices
field_caps-allow_no_indices.description:
If false, the request returns an error if any wildcard expression, index alias,
or `_all` value targets only missing or closed indices. This behavior applies even if the request targets other open indices. For example, a request
targeting `foo*,bar*` returns an error if an index starts with foo but no index starts with bar.

field_caps-expand_wildcards.name: expand_wildcards
field_caps-expand_wildcards.description: The type of index that wildcard patterns can match. If the request can target data streams, this argument determines whether wildcard expressions match hidden data streams. Supports comma-separated values, such as `open,hidden`.

field_caps-fields.name: fields
field_caps-fields.description: A comma-separated list of fields to retrieve capabilities for. Wildcard (`*`) expressions are supported.

field_caps-ignore_unavailable.name: ignore_unavailable
field_caps-ignore_unavailable.description: If `true`, missing or closed indices are not included in the response.

field_caps-include_unmapped.name: include_unmapped
field_caps-include_unmapped.description: If true, unmapped fields are included in the response.

field_caps-filters.name: filters
field_caps-filters.description: A comma-separated list of filters to apply to the response.

field_caps-types.name: types
field_caps-types.description:
A comma-separated list of field types to include.
Any fields that do not match one of these types will be excluded from the results.
It defaults to empty, meaning that all field types are returned.

field_caps-include_empty_fields.name: include_empty_fields
field_caps-include_empty_fields.description: If false, empty fields are not included in the response.

index-id.name: id
index-id.description:
A unique identifier for the document.
To automatically generate a document ID, use the `POST /<target>/_doc/` request format and omit this parameter.

index-index.name: index
index-index.description:
The name of the data stream or index to target.
If the target doesn't exist and matches the name or wildcard (`*`) pattern of an index template with a `data_stream` definition, this request creates the data stream.
If the target doesn't exist and doesn't match a data stream template, this request creates the index.
You can check for existing targets with the resolve index API.

index-if_primary_term.name: if_primary_term
index-if_primary_term.description: Only perform the operation if the document has this primary term.

index-if_seq_no.name: if_seq_no
index-if_seq_no.description: Only perform the operation if the document has this sequence number.

index-include_source_on_error.name: include_source_on_error
index-include_source_on_error.description: True or false if to include the document source in the error message in case of parsing errors.

index-op_type.name: op_type
index-op_type.description:
Set to `create` to only index the document if it does not already exist (put if absent).
If a document with the specified `_id` already exists, the indexing operation will fail.
The behavior is the same as using the `<index>/_create` endpoint.
If a document ID is specified, this paramater defaults to `index`.
Otherwise, it defaults to `create`.
If the request targets a data stream, an `op_type` of `create` is required.

index-pipeline.name: pipeline
index-pipeline.description:
The ID of the pipeline to use to preprocess incoming documents.
If the index has a default ingest pipeline specified, then setting the value to `_none` disables the default ingest pipeline for this request.
If a final pipeline is configured it will always run, regardless of the value of this parameter.

index-refresh.name: refresh
index-refresh.description:
If `true`, Elasticsearch refreshes the affected shards to make this operation visible to search.
If `wait_for`, it waits for a refresh to make this operation visible to search.
If `false`, it does nothing with refreshes.

index-routing.name: routing
index-routing.description: A custom value that is used to route operations to a specific shard.

index-timeout.name: timeout
index-timeout.description:
The period the request waits for the following operations: automatic index creation, dynamic mapping updates, waiting for active shards.

This parameter is useful for situations where the primary shard assigned to perform the operation might not be available when the operation runs.
Some reasons for this might be that the primary shard is currently recovering from a gateway or undergoing relocation.
By default, the operation will wait on the primary shard to become available for at least 1 minute before failing and responding with an error.
The actual wait time could be longer, particularly when multiple waits occur.

index-version.name: version
index-version.description:
An explicit version number for concurrency control.
It must be a non-negative long number.

index-wait_for_active_shards.name: wait_for_active_shards
index-wait_for_active_shards.description:
The number of shard copies that must be active before proceeding with the operation.
